case_vignette: A 25-year-old male presents with 6 months of discoloration in the underarms. He denies any blisters or erosions in the areas. He denies any history of diabetes, insulin resistance, or weight gain. He denies itch. He denies discoloration only with sweating. Physical examination reveals reddish-brown patches in the underarms; Wood's lamp reveals coral red fluorescence.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have had discoloration in my underarms for the past six months.
Have these discolored areas become thicker or have a velvety texture?
No, they have not become thicker or developed a velvety texture.
Do you have any other symptoms such as itching, redness, or pain in the affected area?
No, I do not have itching, redness, or pain in the affected area.
Have you tried any treatments or medications for the discoloration? If so, what were they?
I haven't tried any treatments or medications for the discoloration.
Do you have a history of diabetes or insulin resistance in your family?
I do not have a history of diabetes, insulin resistance, or weight gain.
Are there any changes in the affected areas after exposure to sunlight or heat?
No, the discoloration does not change with sweating.
Is the discoloration only in your underarms, or have you noticed similar changes in other body areas such as the neck or groin?
The discoloration is only in my underarms.
Final Diagnosis: Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation
